After learning a bit more physics, I can say that Derick made a mistake in what's a "misconception". He's right in the sense that heavier objects have more gravitational force,  but that's only if you look at the objects using newtonian mechanics. Using general relativity, you see that both objects are in the same reference frame and it's the frame that's moving. The gravitational force he's speaking of is an emergent propriety from the frame moving relative to the planet's surface and the inertia of the objects.

What I understand as a teen is... If we were to drop both objects from a great height, the heavier object will fall faster due to the presence of air resistance.
F=ma, a=Force/m,
For a falling object through the air, a=(W-Drag)/mass,

[a=g-(Drag/mass)]
A bigger mass means more acceleration.
But for a free-falling object with no air resistance, then the mass of the object does not affect the motion.
[a=g-(zero air resistance/mass)]
[a=g]
All objects fall at the same rate in a vacuum.
Is that way of thinking incorrect? Correct me, please.

G=m*a
9,81*m=m*a

G-Air resistance=m*a
9,81*m-kv=m*a I devide by m on both sides.
9,81-(kv/m)=a You can put in any k or v and you will see that the acceleration will change. Higher mass, higher acceleration. Lets say k is 0,5 and v is 5m/s
a(1kg)=9,81-(2,5/1)=7,31m/s^2

Drop a pin alongside a feather and you will see. You should have dropped both balls from a building with a decent release mechanism. Heavier objects with the same aerodynamic profile fall faster. This is because the pull of gravity is higher on the heavier ball, yet the aerodynamic resistance is the same for each at any given speed. Hence, the heavier ball accelerates faster. Terminal velocity will be higher, too. A basic force balance diagram shows this.

The reason is that there is frictional force counteracting gravitational force. These frictional forces also depend on mass but not so much and depend on the medium (air, concrete, snow ...). Since we eventually divide by mass to retrieve acceleration, the difference in acceleration between two objects is the difference between the tempering by their frictional forces d i v i d e d b y t h e i r m a s s e s. For a heavier object, the tempering by (frictional force / mass) is smaller than for a lighter object, since the frictional force has a less-than-linear relation with mass.

The funny thing is that the more complex phenomenon to explain, is the more intuitive one: heavier objects go faster downhill. This is because in real life, we don't free fall nor do we see objects falling free and live to tell. It takes an - apocryphal - tower of Pisa to do the experiment. Most of the time, we and the objects we observe go down on a slope.

Gravitational force is ALWAYS the same.  Ergo, the force is exactly the same on precise identically SHAPED objects, with precisely identical surfaces, in precisely the same environmental conditions (i.e. air pressure, composition, wind speed).  This is why they use the term "vacuum" as removing all else, is the only way to be sure there are no other influences at the atomic level.  Graviton is constant, regardless of weight, i.e. atomic density, of objects.  However, in the "real-world" there aren't natural vacuums on Earth.  So, it does not matter where you are, or what you drop, there will always be a perceptible difference because there is always stuff between the object and the Earth's surface when you drop things out in the "real-world" in Earth.

This is great if we ignore the negligible effects of air friction, and assuming Newtonian gravity. However, when we invoke General Relativity, there's a lot wrong with this. Let's start by pointing out that gravity is not a force, it is spacetime geometry. Things that are in freefall have no forces acting on them, and if there's no force there is no acceleration. We, the observers, are the ones accelerating, because we're not falling. So the heavier ball does not have more "force" acting upon it. In fact the lighter ball does, because air friction affects it more and slows it down more.

If the height is great enough (i.e. drop them from a height of 1km), the heavier ball will reach the ground faster.
That's because terminal velocity will be higher for the heavier ball (assuming the balls are identical in every other way, except mass).
In other words, both balls accelerate at the same identical rate. But the heavier one will keep accelerating after the lighter ball already reached its "top speed".
Terminal velocity is reached when the gravitational force equals air resistance. As the video said, the force is greater on the heavy object - greater force will need to be balanced by greater air resistance. Greater air resistance implies greater speed.

On the other hand, they would hit at the same time only if they are dropped in a vacuum. Our atmosphere is a “pressure gradient.”  That is, the farther away you get from the surface of the earth, the smaller the pressure is. 
In fact, the atmospheric pressure at your forehead is less than the pressure at your mouth (assuming that you are standing.)  This is equivalent to the buoyant pressure in water.  Our atmosphere is a fluid.

On earth and not in a vacuum, the smaller heavier ball hits the ground first for two reasons:

1. The bouyant force on the larger ball is larger than the buoyant force on the
smaller ball.  The buoyant force is upward, opposite the force from gravity. The buoyant force is trying to slow down
the balls.  It is trying to slow down the larger ball more that the smaller ball because that force is
larger.

2. The larger ball has a larger projected surface area. The drag (force) on the
balls moving thru the fluid air is larger for the larger ball.  It is also in the opposite direction of
the force from gravity.

You would need special instruments to be able to measure which ball hits first.  But, here on
earth, and not in a vacuum, the smaller heavier ball hits first.

Inertia is irrelevant because the inertia of every particle in both balls is the same.  Every particle in the heavier ball is pulled to the ground with the same force that every particle in the lighter ball is pulled.  So...every particle in either ball must fall at the same rate, regardless of the weight of the ball.  Each ball can only fall as fast as the particles in it, so both balls must fall at the same rate.  Particles cannot fall faster just because they are stuck together with other particles.  If heavier objects could fall faster than lighter objects, that would violate the conservation of energy because particles would get energy of motion from merely being connected to other particles, i.e., energy from nowhere.

F = ma (for falling objects a=g or the acceleration of gravity). The force acting on each object is different because of the difference in mass of the balls.  For free falling objects, not considering air resistance or considering in a vaccum, the velocity of both balls falling down from the same height is not dependent on mass. That's why "g" is the same anywhere near the surface of the earth. The acceleration of gravity is a property of the Earth's gravitational field and not a property of the free falling object. In the real world, there is air resistance and friction, counter forces thav=square root (gXheight).  However, we must consider drag force "air resistance" because according to Newton's third law, every action has an opposite and equal reaction. The speed and time at which two objects hit the ground from a drop is dependent on the speed and the cross sectional area of the object, not the mass at all. A bowling ball will hit the ground first than a feather from the same height.

Technically this video is incorrect. In a vacuum with no air resistance, gravity will accelerate the balls at the same rate and they will hit the ground at the same time, but with the air resistance on earth, the heavier ball will accelerate slightly faster than the lighter ball. I am not talking about reaching terminal velocity, I am talking about the actual speed of acceleration.

When dropping them from a few meters as shown in the video, there would be no perceivable difference to a humam because it would be a small fraction of a second difference, but dropping them from about 50-100 feet high (without reaching terminal velocity), you would be able to see the difference.

Lets say you're a raindrop, falling towards the ground. The constant gravitational force acting on you will make the Net Force of your body equal to not zero (Direction towards the ground). Since this is the Net Force, you (The raindrop) will accelerate (Fall towards the ground at an increasing speed). Air resistance and atmospheric pressure may provide an opposition force, therefore affecting the value of the Net Force. As long as they do not provide an opposition force larger than the gravitational pull, making you stay in place or float (Not fall/ Rise) due to the direction of the Net Force, you should be falling.

For basketballs or any other object, the gravitational field strength in their region will always be the same as long as they are in the same region. The weight of the objects may vary due to their masses. Since W (Weight) = M (Mass) * G (Gravitational Field Strength) , (Take G = 9.81) we can say that in this equation, the masses of the objects are the variables. Hence, if one object has a larger mass than the other, that object itself will have more gravitational force acting on it than the other object.

But this does not mean that the heavier object will reach the ground first after falling. The inertia of the object may affect the time taken for the object to fall to the ground. For those who do not know, and for the sake of clearing things, Inertia is defined as the reluctance of an object to move between the states of motion and rest. Therefore, the lighter object will reach the ground earlier than the heavier object as the lighter object is able to move faster than the heavier object.

I disagree.
Gravity isn't a force, so it can't act on any two objects differently.
However, there is a force resulting from earth surface, also known as weight. It depends on the gravitational acceleration of a given location and having a force to push up against gravity. The force is due to the surface stopping the objects motion, and thus where inertia comes into play. The object with more mass, and consequently more inertia, feels heavier because the force to stop its motion is greater.
Without a surface, or an upward force like wind, there is no force involved when free falling in a gravity field, and so you feel weightless.
The acceleration is just an illusion that makes people think its a force. Just like centrifugal acceleration; there is no force acting on you, yet you feel acceleration.

The question was a little ambiguous. People were thinking of "the force of gravity" which can be seen as interacting with atoms or baryons not with "balls". A heavier ball doesn't accelerate slower because it has more inertia from this perspective. If you vaporized both balls into their constituent molecules, all of those molecules would accelerate at 9.8m/s/s at the geoid gravitational isosurface, whether they're all in a lump, or in a cloud. Gravity is acting on both balls in exactly the same way, and it is acting simply on "mass", not on an aggregate with more or less mass, more or less inertia.

If you have a group of 10 runners on a starting line, and a group of 100 runners on another starting line, both masses will accelerate about the same when the gun goes off. The hundred runners will certainly produce more force considered en masse, but their acceleration rate can't be attributed to "greater inertia". Each runner is accelerating at his own unit force/acceleration rate and the average inertia of the group isn't relevant.

Gravity can be considered as a point force acting on an object, like a spring-driven piston. The math and results will work out the same. But it's really not the same process. In some respects gravity is a pseudo-force, like Coriolis or centripetal. It's an acceleration that can be construed as a force, but it's not clear what force is actually being measured when the acceleration of gravity interacts with mass.

What is really happening in this video is that an approximation of the action of gravity is being passed off as if it were a simple, conventional force. People were confused, because it's a confusing, albeit useful and practical, model. If you simply asked "If both balls accelerate at the same rate when pushed across the ground, which will require the greater force?" and of course everyone will nail it. But when you phrase it in terms of "gravitational force" it isn't actually quite the same thing. People fell into the hole between the approximation useful for calculation, and the more obscure reality. They knew that gravity was a constant, but they didn't know quite how to consider the force produced by the interaction of "a mass" - which is a notional entity - and the acceleration of gravity.

"The force is greater, but so is the inertia" can be rattled off fairly smugly. It is a model that produces closely accurate results. But I'm not at all sure that it's correct in its details.

This over simplified explanation feeds into further misconceptions.  For 2 objects of the same shape and volume, the heavier object will ALWAYS hit the ground first because air resistance (which is essentially a function of velocity) will have less of an effect on the heavier object.  The heavier object will take longer to reach terminal velocity and therefore it will be travelling faster.  But importantly prior to reaching terminal velocity the rate of acceleration reduction will be greater for the lighter object, hence it will not travel as far in any given timeframe than the heavier object and will therefore reach the ground after the heavier object has.  I thinks its important explanations to address misconceptions do not create even bigger ones!

The damn force (the weight) is equal to the mass multiplied by the constant (which is not constant) g. So obviously the forces applied are different.
However, we know that the sum of external forces is equal to the mass (m) times the acceleration (a). In this case, if we just ignore the air resistance, which depend mainly on the surface the lower hemisphere of the ball, we get the simple fact that the weight = mass x acceleration. In other words: w = m.a, and given w = m.g, this gives us the simple rule that every high school student knows: if there is no air resistance, and object freely dropped will accelerate with a constant acceleration (linear increase of velocity or speed) equal to g which can be roughly estimated to 9.8m/s/s.
So YES the forces are different, clearly different when you remember the force they exert on your hand when you hold them. And YES, they will both arrive at the same time.

The inertia explination was not very comprehensive. The simple reason as to why they both hit the ground at the same time is because of the gravitation equation: m*a = G*M*m/r^2, where M is the mass of the earth, m is the mass of the ball, G is the gravitational constant, and r is the distance from the object to the center of the earth. Through this equation, we can see that both the 'm's cancel out, which shows that objects experience the same gravitational acceleration regardless of mass (in an ideal situation disregarding air resistance etc). The individual objects DO have different forces acting upon them though, which is easily shown by the fact that F = m*a, showing that force varies by mass.

You should've told them about Terminal Velocity, although that might be an overkill for them :D The reason why both balls are hitting ground simultaneously, is because neither of them has time to reach Terminal Velocity. Assuming you drop them from sufficient height (let's say 200th floor), ball with less mass (and less weight force acting on it) will reach terminal velocity faster and stop accelerating, as drag/resistance (aerodynamic drag in this example) force's vector counteracts weight vector and prevents it from further acceleration. The heavier ball continues to accelerate, as drag needs more time to counteract, so it hits ground first. Eventually heavier ball will also reach terminal velocity, but it will be faster.

Interestingly in vacuum, there is no drag and only gravity is affecting them, so both balls will hit ground exactly at the same time, heck even if you put a feather there, it will drop with the same speed :)

Let say the mass of those two balls is m1 and m2 (m1>m2)

If the ball is freefalling, there are two force act upon it: the gravity force ( F(g) ) and air resistance force ( f )

Because f have opposing direction against F(g), also we set the direction of F(g) is positive, then the total force will be (assume the air resistance force is the same on two balls):

<Ball 1>: m1a1 = F1 = F1(g)-f = m1g-f <=> m1a1 = m1g-f <=> a1 = g-f/m1
<Ball 2>: m2a2 = F2 = F2(g)-f = m2g-f <=> m2a2 = m2g-f <=> a2 = g-f/m2

Because m1>m2 => g-f/m1 > g-f/m2 => a1>a2

Of course they will only actually fall at the same rate in a vacuum. If the balls were identical in dimensions and surface texture the heavier (more massive) one will be slowed less by atmospheric drag. Ultimately the heavier one will have a higher terminal velocity (reached when the force exerted by gravity is balanced by the upward one of atmospheric drag). The heavier one will also accelerate faster, albeit only fractionally so at low velocities. Try dropping those balls from a tower rather than from head height and the difference would be obvious, albeit rather dangerously so in the case of the medicine ball.

People are confused because air resistance isn't addressed. The girl asked "...in real life?" ... I think it's safe to say that means not in a vacuum. In real life falling speed is influenced, not by weight, but by size and shape because they affect the role played by (invisible) matter obstructing the path from the object to the earth. Earth pulls harder on a heavier object, but needs to pull harder to move it because it is heavier. However, the more molecules in the air an object has to displace, and the harder it is to displace them (shape, roughness of surface) to be able to move through this air (in this case towards the ground I.e. the center of the earth) the more it will be slowed down.

the acceleration of an object is a result of the ratio of the force applied to the object and the objects mass; a=F/m. Since the force in this case is due to gravity and the only acceleration applied is gravity, the equation becomes a=mg/m. The mass cancels out which implies the acceleration of any object in free fall is is equal to the acceleration of gravity. Hence, objects of different masses fall with the same constant acceleration though more massive objects will result in a greater force. also, though the acceleration is constant throughout, the velocity, obviously, isn't, since acceleration is a rate of change in velocity. the objects land with the same velocity but the velocity isn't constant throughout

So I've been doing some thinking about how gravity works, and it dawned on me that the typical 9.8m/s^2 value of acceleration that we are all accustomed to, although very pragmatic, works in a very specific set of circumstances. Typically this experiment is done with objects that have a contrast in weight with one another such as an orange and a rock. And we see the quite noticeable proportionality of force acting on an object in respect to the object's mass, making things accelerate at a constant rate. Now it doesn't take a physics major to acknowledge that things like wind resistance can cause different objects to have unique terminal velocities. But even in a vacuum, can we still say for sure that both objects are actually hitting at the same time, or for all intensive purposes, accelerating towards earth at the same rate? One thing I noticed is that, although the experiment always considers two objects of differing masses to one another, they are in retrospect all insignificantly tiny in comparison to the earth itself. This may not seem very startling, but consider a different set of objects in the same experiment. What if we used something MUCH bigger, like the moon and an orange for example? Suppose, that we have an earth, vacant of atmosphere so we aren't worrying ourselves about friction, and we can for all intensive purposes, spontaneously create both an orange and a moon, both equal distance from the center of the earth, and record the results. Now besides the moon and earth colliding with one another, causing untold catastrophes that I'm sure could be described in great detail for hours, would the two objects actually fall towards the earth at the same acceleration and velocities? Remember that all physical bodies have a gravitational force which, from our current understanding of physics, reaches infinitely to all other mass in the universe. Even the smallest and lightest objects still have a gravitational pull, they are simply so insignificantly tiny that they are quite literally unmeasurable with our given level of technology. But does that truly make them non-existent? We know that the moon does in fact pull on the earth a noticeable amount, causing tides to rise and fall, and our orbit to actually wobble. So if they were to in fact be in free fall towards one another, would there be the same level of acceleration for that set period of time? the magnitude of the acceleration that one body causes on another is the mass of the gravitating body divided by the distance between those two centers of mass squared (g = M/d^2). So acceleration caused by an object has nothing to do with the mass of the object its pulling on. However, since the other object is also causing an acceleration of its own, then the two objects accelerating towards one another give one greater net acceleration. And typically, this discrepancy would be unmeasurable since, we can't measure the acceleration of gravity caused by rocks and oranges on planetary bodies. But again, does this make it non-existent? So if the moon and orange were dropped at the same time, would they actually collide at the same time? Assuming they were dropped on the same side, or at least as close as possible considering how wide the moon is in relation, the fact that their respective vectors would be quite similar, they would both be causing the earth to accelerate towards them in one summation. But if we dropped them at opposite sides of the earth, I think it would be quite easy to see why they may not in fact collide at the same time. So as impractical as it may be to consider, the idea that acceleration on two objects dropped from the same height towards a gravity well will be the same, is as I stated before, a mere mechanical practicality, and not an absolute truth. Yes the acceleration caused by earth will be the same, but the net acceleration between the two bodies will most definitely be different.

The acceleration due to the Earth's gravity is equal on all falling objects within the gravitational field. The velocity/speed of the object varies depending on aerodynamics and the density of the surrounding material. The force depends upon how massive the object is. Our senses can trick us into thinking that heavy things fall faster because they are more difficult to hold. But the truth is that when you are holding a heavy object, the force due to gravity is still acting upon it. We feel the force of our hands countering the force of gravity. The ball is always accelerating at 9.8m/s/s, from the perspective of the Earth's center. For us to hold the ball in place, we need to exert a force equal in magnitude and negative of the force of gravity. It's easier to understand if you think about it as you playing tug of war with the Earth, except the Earth always wins.

Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation tells us that the two planets will pull each other with a force equal to the gravitational constant times the mass of both objects, divided by the distance between the center of both objects.  This looks like:  Force = 6.674x10-11 N m / kg2  (Earth's mass x Neptune's mass) / d2.  Both will accelerate towards each other, however the planet with the greater mass will accelerate at a slower rate because acceleration = force / mass.

This is only correct if the 2 objects are dropped simulteneously in a vacuum.

Unfortunately out in the real world the experiment fails because you are dropping the objects through a viscous medium, ie air.

An Object dropped through air will initially accelerate due to gravity and will speed up.
The air it is falling thru will produce an upward force that increases with the speed.
At a certain speed the upward force from the air will equal and fully oppose the downward force from gravity.
The object will no longer accelerate as the downward force is matched by the upward force and will now remain at a steady speed.(assume air density constant)
This steady speed is called terminal velocity.

This terminal velocity will not be the same for both objects.
The heavier object will require more upward force from the air than the lighter object before it matches the downward force from gravity.
Hence the heavy object will reach a higher terminal velocity, hence they will not fall at the same speed and WILL NOT HIT THE GROUND AT THE SAME SPEED.

The formulae for terminal velocity in air, or any viscous fluid can be calculated, but for those of you who want an easy to percieve example:

Imagine I have 2 objects identical in size but of very different material density.
One is a thick sheet of cardboard, the other is a thick sheet of lead.
I hold them both flat in the palms of my hands and then let them fall simulteneously from a 3rd floor window.
Now ask your self: Which one is going to hit the ground first ? and then ask yourself why ?

In response to all the misled commenters down below:

1. There is no rate of acceleration. Acceleration is the rate of velocity, (change in distance over change in time). The acceleration for any falling object on Earth (ignoring air resistance) is 9.8 m/s^2. This means that the acceleration rate (the rate at which acceleration changes) must be zero. Anything else would contradict what we established earlier.

2. Massive objects have more force acting upon them. but they also have more mass. The force-to-mass ratio doesn't change, hence, neither does acceleration.

This is not actually true. If you'd take this explanation only (and not the full explanation), airplanes should be made from heavy metals instead of light ones. See the bottom of this comment explaining why (but read the top part first).

They do not accelerate at the same rate. The heavy ball does accelerate faster, by a small bit. That's because the resistance by the air is the same with both balls (assuming they've got the same texture etc.). But, since the gravitational force is larger on the heavier ball, the effect of this resistance (an opposing force) will be less significant.
Let's take the example of a metal ball and a styrofoam ball. I am sure everybody will know that the metal ball will hit the ground first. That's because the styrofoam ball will have a downward force that's much smaller than that of the metal ball, so the opposing (upward) force of the air resistance (which is equal to that of the metal ball) will have a proportionally larger effect. Perhaps the air resistance will cancel out half of the downward force on the styrofoam ball, but less than a tenth of the metal ball. That means that the overall acceleration of the metal ball will still be greater than that of the styrofoam ball, so it will land first.

In fact, if this wasn't the case, long-distance airplanes would probably have been made out of heavier metals, because they'd require less fuel to maintain their speeds (inertia). The only thing preventing that is the fact that air resistance has a proportionally larger effect on light objects than on heavy objects. So no, this is not just a pedantic statement (it just partially is). It also has real-life situations this applies to.

If I may submit a small algebraic explaination.
Take the mass of the orange ball (m1) to equal x and take the mass of the black ball (m2) to equal 5x.

As we all will remember from somewhere; F=ma where
F=Force accelerating acting on the object
m=The objects mass
a=The objects acceleration
For the purposes of this explaination, let a=y


The force acting on the orange ball=F1
F1=m1*a
F1=x*y
F1=xy

For the force acting on the black ball=F2
F2=m2*a
F2=5x*y
F2=5xy


Now to calculate the rate at which the object will accelerate toward the earth which can be given by   a=F/m

For the acceleration of the orange ball=a1
a1=F1/m1
a1=(xy)/x
a1=y

For the acceleration of the black ball=a2
a2=F2/m2
a2=(5xy)/5x
a2=y


so, a1=a2=y=g=9.81ms-2
In other words, the acceleration of both objects are equal.
The the force acting on the black ball may be greater than that of the orange ball, but its mass is also greater by the same factor. The extra force will be "use up" in making the black ball move. The two balls will then accelerate at the same rate.

If there was no gravity the balls would not fall. Since the earth exerts the same force the balls, for earth to pull the heavier ball is harder than to pull the lighter ball, which would mean that the heavier ball had to land on the ground later than would the lighter ball! If that is the case so why do the balls land on the ground at the same time? This eluded newton and so to explain this phenomenon he suggested that there is a attraction between all objects (masses), which is proportional to the product of their mass and inversely proportional to the distance square between them. For our case, the heavier ball has a greater attraction towards the earth, since it has a greater mass, but because it has a greater 'inertia'=( resistance to movement), its greater attraction towards the earth is equalised by having a greater inertia, its resistance to movement, which requires a greater force to be accelerated. The same applies for the lighter ball. It has a less attraction towards the earth, since it has a less mass, but, at the same time, it has a less inertia (requires less force to be accelerates),as it has a less mass. Therefore the balls fall at the same rate. However, the resultant force acting on them is not the same. There is a greater resultant force acting on the heavier ball and that is why it feels heavier. I hope this has made it reasonable for you as to why everything falls at the same rate.

Let me try to clear up some confusion about air resistance

The air resistance on an object does not depend on the mass of the object.
The formula for calculating the aerodynamic drag on an object is
D=(1/2)(Cd)(rho)(A)(V^2)
Where,
D = Drag force
Cd = drag coefficient of the object, which is determined by its shape/geometry
rho (Greek letter) = density of air (Varies with altitude)
A = Cross sectional area of the object relative to the "wind" direction (in other words,
       the 2D area of the object that the "wind" "sees"), which for a ball would be 
       Pi*R^2
V^2 = Velocity of the object through the air, squared

Now if you balance forces acting on the object (with down as positive) you have
mg - (1/2)(Cd)(rho)(A)(V^2) = ma

So, if you had two balls (equal shape/geometry and thus Cd) that have equal size (equal A), and different masses (and thus different densities), the ball with the higher mass (higher density) would fall faster. (g and rho would be equal) (solve for a)

Lets say we dropped 2 balls (equal in every way except mass/density) with an initial velocity, V. Then both balls would have the same drag, D. Lets say D = 2 and gravity = g = 10, which is also the same for both balls. Now lets say ball 1 has a mass of 3 and ball 2 has a mass of 4.
The acceleration of ball 1 would be
(3*10)2=3*a   --->   a = 28/3 = 9.33333
The acceleration of ball 2 would be
(4*10)2=4*a   --->   a = 38/4 = 9.5

9.5 is greater than 9.33333, thus the more massive/heavier/denser ball will drop faster.

In summary, it is because aerodynamic drag does not depend on the objects mass that you cannot remove the mass of the object from the balanced equation, and thus the mass of the object does effect how fast it would fall. If you don't include air resistance, the above equation becomes mg=ma. The objects mass in this equation doesn't matter and is why we know that all objects accelerating at the "same" rate.

FYI: If you set a=0 in the above equation and solve for V you get the objects terminal velocity. Also with this rearranged equation, you would see that an object with twice as much mass/density (same size and shape) as another object would have a terminal velocity about 1.4 times (or the square root of 2) that of the other object.

The fact that both falling objects hit the floor at the same time can also be explained with the law of conservation of energy, which states that it is impossible to create or destroy energy. Energy can merely be transformed from one form to another.

An object with a certain mass (m) held at a certain height (h) from the earths surface will have a potential energy of:
Ep = m*h*g (where g is earths gravitational accelleration constant ~9.81 m/s^2).
When that object is released, the potential energy gets transformed into kinetic energy as it is accellerated by Earths gravitational force. The formula for kinetic energy is: Ek = 0.5*m*v^2.(where v is the velocity of the object).
When the object reaches the earths surface, all of its potential energy will have been tranformed into kinetic energy:
Ep = Ek = m*g*h = 0.5*m*v^2
From this we can deduce that: g*h = 0.5*v^2
The velocity of the object hitting the ground is: v = sqrt(2*g*h)

This velocity is thus independent from the mass that it has! Which means that it does not matter what the mass of the objects are. As long as they are dropped from the same height they will hit the ground at the same speed (ignoring any possible air friction).
Since the start and end speed are the same for both objects and the travelled distance is the same, the accelleration must also be the same (which is g) and therefore the time it takes to travel that distance is also the same.

That is not true. The graviational force F(g)=mg. Mass multiplied by 9.81. That makes the force. So let's say a ball of 2Kg.
F(g)=2x9.81
F(g)=19.62
That is the amount of force you have to apply on the ball to keep it where it is.
If you let it fall, then F(g)=F(a)
We know that F(g)=19.62
F(a)=ma
m (mass) is 2Kg.
19.62=2a
19.62/2=a
9.81=a
If we take 20Kg, then we multiply 9.81 by 20, and then divide by 20 making it 9.81.
And that is why they fall at the same speed.

In formulas: M*a=M*g*h-Rfric  ->  a=g*h-Rfric/M 

where a is the acceleration of the body, M its mass, g=9.81m/s/s, h heigh of the fall and Rfric the friction that could be considered  a constant for small speed variation.

Conclusion: due to the presence of Rfric the acceleration of the body is greater when more important is its mass (i.e. the ratio -Rfric/M is smaller and the other term g*h is less reduced). With no air and no friction, objects fall at the same time.

How the difference in weight between the two balls causes the gravitational force to be greater but inertia also causes the gravitational acceleration to remain the same.

Gravitational Pull Force on Heavier ball (F1)= M.g
Gravitational Pull Force on Lighter ball (F2) = m.g
M>m --> F1 > F2 
Coming to the Energy Conservation (for Time taken by balls),
Gravity Potential of mass M at Height h = M.g.h
Which is again equal to;
Kinetic energy of that mass at the moment of contact at the ground = ½.M.v.v (v = velocity of the mass at the time of contact with ground)
Now, this means:
g.h = ½.v.v;
which implies, v is only a function of constant 'g' and the initial height 'h', irrespective of mass (m).
Hence, the time taken by two balls are same irrespective of their mass differences.

Wrong.

AT terminal velocity, the object has reached a velocity where the upward force of drag is equal to the downward force of gravity.  The net force acting on the body is zero, therefore the acceleration is also zero.  The velocity remains constant.

In a vacuum, there is no drag, so there is NEVER a force that counters gravity, so the acceration never decreases, because drag never increases.  The body will continue to accelerate consistent with gravity alone.  The velocity will continue to increase

As the object falls, the faster it goes, and the lower the net force.

Example :

Toward the beginning of a fall, the downward force of gravity is much greater than the upward force of drag.  The net acceleration is downward, but not quite 9.8 m/s² because drag is countering some of that.

Just before reaching terminal velocity, the downward force of gravity is only slightly more than the upward force of drag, so there is still downward acceleration, just not much.

"They will only land at the same time if they both have the same amount of resistance"

Not true.  They would also have to have the same shape and mass if the air resistance is the same (to land at the same time).  If drag were the same for two objects of different mass, then that drag will result in a higher acceleration for a lesser massive object.  This is why drag is ignored when addressing fundamental gravitation. It's a lot more complicated than people think, and comments like this hurt.

An astronaut did a similar experiment on the Moon. He dropped a feather and a hammer from the same altitude, and they reached the ground at the same time. On Earth, they'll obviously hit the ground at a different time, due to the air resistance acting on the  objects. So yeah, to your question, if you drop a piece of paper and a missile from 100m with 0 initial velocity, there'll both reach the bottom at the same time.

They will only land at the same time if they both have the same amount of resistance, in your example the missile would land first because it is more aerodynamic and the paper would get disrupted by air resistance and wind. If they were both released at the same time in a vacuum, where there is no air resistance or wind, they would land at the same time. I hope this helps!

Be careful.  Saying "gravity would have the same effect" can be misleading.  It is important to understand that the FORCE of gravity is different - and greater on the more massive object, and that the ACCELERATION is the same (for two objects at the same height).  You shouldn't say they fall at the same 'speed', but rather they fall at the same rate of acceleration.

think of the 2 balls as being bags of sand, the light one loosely packed, the heavy one with more sand. Gravity would have the same effect on all the sand no matter how much sand was in the bags. All the sand would fall at the same speed.

The missile would hit first because of the fact that, particularly over a greater height such as you are talking about, wind and particle resistance would take a greater effect on the paper due to it having such high drag. However; theoretically, in a vacuum they would fall at the same rate. This was tested on the Moon when an astronaut dropped a hammer and a feather. They fell at the same rate in a vacuum. The results in air are totally different because of their different aerodynamics.

Think about this problem as if all the atoms in an object were not connected to any other atoms.  Picture all those atoms standing on a cliff and jumping off at the same time.  That's how to make sense of it.

No, it is to do with air resistance. The air resistance depends on the area of the bottom of an object, not mass, so lighter objects that are the same shape are lifted more by air resistance. In a vacuum, everything falls at the same rate.

Air resistance plays a role in the final acceleration of the object. The gravitational force down is counteracted by the force due to air resistance up. Not every object will reach the ground at the same time when dropped from the same altitude. A missle will reach the bottom of a 100m fall first because the sum of the gravitational force on the missle + the opposing air resistance force results in a greater downward acceleration than the paper will have after the sum of the forces acting on it.

Air drag is not taken into account in this experiment. While two identical spheres of similar mass fall at the same acceleration, your piece of paper and missile are too different from each other (they would fall at the same rate only on the moon for instance)

You are mostly right, but it is a little misleading to say that the acceleration is 'constant'.  The more appropriate description is that acceleration is THE SAME for two bodies falling in the same gravitational field who are the same distance from the source of that field. You should be careful with your variables.  G and g are two different things.  G is the gravitational constant, while g is the local acceleration due to gravity.  g is the proper variable to use in this equation which is the exact same thing as F=ma.  Force is equal to mass times acceleration.  W=mg - Weight (a force) is equal to the mass times the acceleration (due to gravity).  You don't just say mass * gravity.  You could mean several different things.  It's the ACCELERATION DUE TO gravity.

9.8 m/s² is not the FORCE due to gravity.  9.8 m/s² is the ACCELERATION due to gravity.  Acceleration due to gravity IS the same regardless of the mass, and the force of gravity is directly proportional to mass.  Did you even watch the video?  F=ma - Force is equal to the mass times the acceleration.  You can rearrange to solve for a and get 

a=F/m

If a is always equal to 9.8 m/s² (at the surface), then you can see that the higher mass gets, the more force is required to accelerate at 9.8 m/s²

And just FYI, if you are going to consider drag, then the balls need not reach terminal velocity in order for there to be a difference.  Objects do not fall at the same rate until they all reach their respective terminal velocities. The person in this video is talking about fundamental gravitation.  Trust me; he is well aware of the effects of drag, but when teaching fundamental gravitation, drag is always ignored.  If you pick up any entry-level physics text book, you will find that it will ignore drag as well.  Drag comes later, and you will never learn how drag affects a falling object if you don't first have a grasp on how gravity alone affects it. Inertia is the key here. It takes more force to move a body at rest if that object is heavier, but is has more inertia. The heavier the object, the more force is exerted on it, but the more inertia it takes to accelerate. The lighter the object, less force is exerted on it, and less inertia to accelerate. But the key here is that the ratio of force to inertia is the same for all objects. So it hit the ground at the same time.

Terminal velocity is reached when the force of gravity (weight) is equal to the force of drag (and buoyancy, but in air, its irrelevant).

But an objects mass relative to the mass of air is a factor, so mass is related to the effect air resistance has on the acceleration.

I like to use the comparison of the International Space Station with a pencil floating inside.  They are both free falling, and the ISS is obviously WAY more massive than the pencil inside, yet they both accelerate at the exact same rate.  If objects of different mass accelerated at different rates, the concept of a space station could never work.

If two objects have the same size and shape, the more massive object will accelerate at a higher rate in air (not in a vacuum).  While the force of drag itself does not depend on the mass of the object, the resulting acceleration of that object certainly depends on mass.  The more massive ball will resist the drag force more efficiently than the less massive ball will.  In other words, the force of drag (even though it's actually less) on the less massive ball will slow it down more.

Part 5 (last) :

The demonstration in this video is of two balls being dropped simultaneously.  Since they are being dropped from the same height, the acceleration (due to gravity - ignoring drag) is exactly the same for each. The Earth is not accelerating more toward one ball because they are being dropped at the same time, so even considering the Earth's acceleration, it is doing so toward the combined mass of BOTH balls, and will accelerate toward BOTH balls and they will land simultaneously.

Part 4 :

I should mention that the two cars in my scenario ARE in inertial reference frames (since they are not accelerating)...The person on the ground is just in a fixed frame and able to observe the independent motion of each car.  The point is that even though you can add the accelerations together, that doesn't mean you can say that the more massive ball accelerates more.  It still accelerates at the exact same rate relative to a fixed frame, and the Earth accelerates independently.

Part 3 :

"And wouldn't it's acceleration combine with earth's acceleration to be a little bit more?" - only from the reference frame of either the object or the Earth.  The Earth's acceleration is entirely independent (however negligibly small it is).  It is like two cars passing each other on the highway while one is going 60mph and the other is going 1 mph.  They see each other pass at 61 mph, but to someone on the ground (inertial frame), they see one going 1 mph and the other going 60 mph.

Part 1

"....9.8 m/s^2 regardless of mass and therefore is constant?" - yes and no.  9.8 m/s² is not a constant, but an average along the surface.  Another factor in gravitational force (and by extension, acceleration) is the distance between the objects.  In this case, between the centers of an object and the Earth.  Since the elevation on Earth varies, so does your distance at the surface, and therefore force.  However, acceleration IS constant no matter the mass given the same distance.

In other words, the 'F' in the equation can represent ANY force, and if you choose to represent drag, then the equation most certainly accounts for drag.  It will not help you calculate the force of drag, but assuming you know the mass of the falling body, if you know either the acceleration due to drag or the force due to drag, the equation can be used to calculate the force or the acceleration respectively, and is appropriate.

F=ma is a universal law of motion that states ANY force is equal to the mass of the object that 'receives' the force multiplied by the acceleration of that object (including drag).  If you know the force of drag, it can certainly be used.  For example, if I weigh 150 lbs (~68kg), then the Earth exerts a force of ~667 Newtons on me. a=F/m (same equation) says that my acceleration is 9.8m/s². If the force of drag is 500 Newtons (in that moment) then the NET force acting is 167 Newtons - a=2.45m/s²

It wouldn't matter if it was a ball and a 747.  They would still fall at the same rate.  Take the astronauts and the space station.  The astronauts' mass compared to the entire space station is tiny, yet they are in orbit (free fall) around the Earth, and are accelerating at the same rate.  It has nothing to do with the mass of the falling body.  The accelerations are exactly the same (from the same height) for everything regardless of their mass.

The gravitational pull is not equal, the heavier ball is pulled with a stronger force. It is just that the difference of the mass within the two balls are small enough compared to the mass of earth, to make it look like the balls hit the ground at the same time.

Terminal velocity has everything to do with mass.  Terminal velocity is when the force of drag is equal to the force of gravity.  The more massive the object is, the more force due to gravity there is.  This means that it requires more drag force to equal the force of gravity.  Since you cannot change the shape of the object falling, the only variable that CAN change that effects drag is velocity.  Ergo, more mass = higher terminal velocity.  It has to do with BOTH drag AND mass.

F=GM1M2/r²
F=ma - - the 'm' represents the same 'M2' from the above formula so it can be written

Gravity does not equal mass times distance.  Mass and distance are just the relevant variables when calculating the force.  The more mass there is, the more force there is.  The closer the two objects are together, the more force there is.  Technically, the force of gravity is in direct proportion to the product of the masses (M1 * M2), and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them (r²).  The equation is F=GM1M2/r².  And yes, heavier means more force.  Weight IS a force.

Here's another way to look at this.  What's really going on when a 10kg bowling ball traveling say 10m/s hits a scale, is it is being accelerated upward (decelerated) at a VERY high rate. F=ma, so the force on that 10kg ball is 1,000 Newtons when it hits the scale.  However, it's weight is always 98 Newtons.  Momentum is why.

You are talking about momentum. The weight is not changing.  A scale does not measure weight.  A scale is just measuring force.  Momentum (p) is mass(m) times velocity(v)  p=mv.  The more momentum an object has, the greater the force the scale will exert when something with momentum lands on it.  If you stand still on a scale (velocity = 0), then you have 0 momentum, and the scale is indeed measuring your weight (force due to gravity).

Think of an object as a collection of particles. Each particle has inertial mass X and gravitational mass Y.

Here is a formula for TV...
√(2mg/CpA)

Where:
m = mass of the object,
g = acceleration due to gravity (in a vacuum near the surface of the planet)
C = an experimentally determined constant, inversely proportional to the aerodynamic-ness of the object. (smaller for more aerodynamic objects)
p = density of the air
A = area of the largest 2d cross-section of the object, perpendicular to the path of travel (so in this case horizontal).

Correction - ma = GmM/r² simplified to a = GM/r²

So as you can see, "a = GM/r²" only contains the mass of the Earth.  The mass of any object free falling on Earth is irrelevant when calculating the acceleration.

M = ~5.972 * 10^24 kg
r = ~6,375,000 meters at the surface.  (r = distance from the center of mass of the [ball in this case] to the center of the Earth)
G = ~6.67 * 10^-11 (gravitational constant)

a = (6.67 * 10^-11) * (5.972 * 10^24) / (6,375,000²) = 9.8 m/s²

The only mass that is relevant when calculating the acceleration of a falling body on Earth is the mass of the Earth.

F=ma means that any force is equal to the mass of the object times the acceleration.  There is another equation to calculate the gravitational attraction between two objects (Earth and ball) it is F = GmM/r², where m is the mass of the 'ball', and M is the mass of the Earth.  This means ma = mM/r². The 'm' cancels on each side, and you are left with a = M/r².

Not at a constant rate (as far as speed is concerned).  It is not in a perfectly circular orbit, so the speed does vary depending on a few things, but the speed stays relatively constant.  The space station IS constantly accelerating in general however.  Acceleration is a change in velocity, which means a change in direction is just as much an acceleration as a change in speed is, and the space station is most certainly constantly changing direction.

In other words, a person outside either frame of reference would observe the moon accelerate toward the Earth at 32 ft/s², and the Earth accelerate toward the moon at a different (and much slower) rate.  You cannot combine the two and claim that it is the acceleration of the moon by itself.  That's at best careless.  The acceleration of the moon, basketball, medicine ball, etc. are all identical (if dropped from the same height). The acceleration of the Earth toward them is entirely independent.

I don't know what you are arguing anymore.  If you are trying to imply that a more massive body will accelerate at a higher rate than a less massive one, you are very wrong.  My only (and whole) argument is that the acceleration of a falling body toward the Earth is the same regardless if the falling body has the mass of a basketball, or the mass of the moon.  I'm not saying that the acceleration of the Earth toward the 'moon' is not relevant, I'm saying it is independent of it.

The earth itself may only pull at 32 ft/s^2 (beans on your metric system), but the moon is also pulling the earth.    From either frame of reference, the other frame of reference would be moving at (approximately) the combined speed.

Even if you were to assume the earth immovable and ONLY the moon to be moving, the moon's gravitational force would still pull toward the earth, thus pulling itself to the earth.  Forces would combine.
Does the space station accelerate in speed around the earth?

BUT the acceleration of the moon is still the same as the ball.  If you were standing on the moon or the Earth during this experiment, you would observe an acceleration equal to the sum of both the moon and Earth, but now you are no longer in an inertial frame of reference so your observations would not represent the accelerations someone in an inertial frame of reference would observe.  If the ball accelerated at 9.81 m/s², the moon would also be accelerated at 9.81 m/s².

If you were to 'drop' the moon onto the Earth from a relatively short distance, the moon would accelerate toward the Earth at the exact same rate as a basketball would given they are dropped from the same height.  However, the Earth would have a then measurable acceleration toward the moon, and the moon would reach the Earth before the ball, but only because the Earth is measurably accelerating as well (their NET accelerations are greater than that of the ball-earth scenario)...continued

I never said gravity was a constant.  I said the acceleration DUE to gravity was constant (on Earth from the same distance from the center).  You are talking about the NET acceleration.  Yes, technically the Earth is 'falling' toward the balls as well, and THAT rate is different depending on the ball's mass, but the rate at which the balls fall toward the Earth is the same (or constant).  Even in the most practical application, the Earth's acceleration would be toward both balls regardless.

Just want to clarify that the acceleration on Earth is not a constant.  It depends where you are on Earth, and what your elevation (distance to center) you are.  9.81m/s² is a ballpark average.  It varies over the surface.  However, two balls dropped from the same height and location relative to the center of the Earth will experience virtually identical accelerations.  I just wanted to clear up the part about acceleration being a constant.

(Force)=(Mass)x(Acceleration)
Objects on earth have an acceleration of 9.81m/s^2 toward the ground. Therefore, since the acceleration is always constant on earth, and you multiply it by the mass of the mass of the object the obtain the force needed to move it, the object with greater mass has the most force acting upon it.

If the forces were the same for both, this would be true.  However, this is not the case.  The force of gravity depends on mass, and the more mass, the greater the force, therefore, they accelerate at the same rate.

9.81 m/s² is just an average, and it only applies to bodies very near the surface.  It varies over the surface because the Earth is not a perfect sphere, and it decreases when your distance to the center of the Earth increases (i.e. the acceleration for astronauts in orbit is around 8.8 m/s²).

No.  The more dense object will immediately start accelerating faster than the less dense object (less weight, more drag).    Terminal velocity is simply where  force due to drag in viscous medium is exactly equal and opposite the force due to gravity x mass, but the relative imbalance in drag between the heavy/dense object and lighter/less dense object is the same all the time.    Drag goes up by square of velocity though, so it's not noticed immediately.
Because water is a liquid and it has different chemical properties to air which is a gas, yes?

Not only is terminal velocity not a constant for all objects, some objects can have several terminal velocities depending on their orientation.  A sky diver has a lower terminal velocity while in the spread eagle position than he'she does while in the tuck or feet-first position.  Terminal velocity is reached when the force of drag equals the force of gravity.  Since the force of gravity depends on mass, then the drag force required to reach terminal velocity indirectly relies on mass as well.
1.6m/s² is the acceleration due to gravity of the moon.  It has nothing to do with any kind of 'resistance'.

You said, "[drag force] is not dependent on mass"

While this in itself is an accurate statement, the affect drag force has on an object is ENTIRELY dependent on mass.  If you have two bodies that are identical in every way except one has more mass, and these two bodies are dropped through an atmosphere, the more massive body will reach the ground first because the drag force on both bodies are the same, and that drag force has a greater affect on the less massive body.

Air is a fluid so the affects of buoyancy are present in air as well.  It's why helium rises.  It floats on air.  If the amount of water that is displaced by an object weighs more than the object itself, then the object will float.  Divers would float even though they have a tank attached to their back because they have air in their lungs, air in the tank, and usually air-filled cells in their wetsuits.  They wear weight-belts because the water they displace weighs a lot less than the weight.

The reason a feather 'floats' down when you drop it in our atmosphere is because it reaches terminal velocity almost instantly.  Terminal velocity is reached when the upward drag force is equal to the downward gravitational force.  The projected surface area and mass of an object are what affect drag force the most.  A feather has a large surface area for its small mass so the terminal V is low.  You're not completely wrong, you are just adding an irrelevant 3rd dimension by measuring volume.

Part 4 (FINAL) :  I want to note that I did take into account the extra mass to consider for the acceleration of the penny in both scenarios.  In the hypothetical-sized ball, the change in accleration for the penny went from 9.8m/s^2 to about 9.9m/s^2, so not much.  In the moon-sized scenario, the change was negligible.  Thanks for the question.  It was a very interesting one, and I was suprised to find that the penny would land first if the 'ball' were actually the size of the moon.

Part 3 :  If the ball is actually the SIZE of the moon also, then the penny would definitely hit first.  Their centers of mass are now much farther apart so the 'ball' NOW would accelerate toward the Earth at a slower 6.05 m/s^2 while the Earth would accelerate toward the ball at a snail-like .074 m/s^2 taking 5.71 seconds for the Earth-ball collision to occur while the penny is still accelerating at 9.8 m/s^2 taking about 4.5 seconds to fall.  This is a bit counterintuitive.

Part 2 :  I did some calculations, and if the 'ball' were just a hypothetical ball that had the mass of the moon, then the penny and the ball would collide with Earth at almost the same time.  The Earth-Ball collision WOULD happen a fraction of a second before the penny hit because the Earth would be pulled toward the ball at a rate of .12m/s^2.  It would take 4.59 seconds for this collision to occur so the Earth would have only moved about half a meter.  This is why the penny barely hits 2nd.

This is interesting.  Does the ball that has the mass of the moon also have the size of the moon, or are we pretending that it is just a hypothetical ball you can hold in your hand?  The reason I ask this is because if it were the actual size of the moon, then to calculate the force of gravity between the two, the distance you use is between their centers of mass, which are much farther apart if it is the size of the moon resulting in a signigicant drop in the rate of acceleration.

As far as gravity is concerned, volume is irrelevant.  It does not matter what the volume of an object is.  All that matters is the mass of the object, so a feather and a hammer are a perfectly valid demonstration of how gravity accelerates objects at the same rate regardless of mass.  If you wanted to calculate the force of gravity between objects, all you would need to know are their masses, and the distance between their centers of mass.  Not volume.  Volume absolutely does not matter.

Just to point out a few things from this post.

1.  Time dilation does not prove curved space time, though I am not saying gravity does not cause a curvature (because it does), I am merely pointing out that time dilation is in no way proof that it does

2.  You need not be in a gravitational field for time dilation to occur.

3.  Time dilation is not caused by acceleration.

4.  Time slows down relative to an object in proportion to its speed, so clocks on Earth would be FASTER..not slower.

Nobody has overturned Newton's laws of motion or the universal theory of gravitation in 300 years. It still remains remarkably accurate for applications within the Solar system, and will remain so in perpetuity. What has changed (thanks to Einstein) is our understanding of what happens in more extreme cases (larger dimensions, greater  velocities & masses). Newton's equations are accurate enough for most practical uses and are in fact what's used for all navigation of probes and manned missions.

No. Here's why:
F=ma
and
F=G(mM)/R^2
thus:
ma = G(mM)/R^2

Where:
m - mass of ball
a - acceleration
G - gravitational constant
M - mass of Earth
R - distance from ball's center of mass to Earth's center of mass

The 'm' cancels out, leaving:
a = GM/R^2

So the acceleration only depends on the mass of the Earth and the distance to it's center of mass, not on the mass of the ball.

@iamgig9876 The speed of the earth's revolution around the sun is constant. This is a consequence of F=ma, because there is no component of acceleration in line with the earth's movement, only perpendicular, so speed is constant. This is one of the observations that lead to kepler's second law, that equal areas are swept by the orbit of a planet with equal time.

@iamgig9876 The reason the moon is moving away from the earth is that the moon-earth system is actually losing energy. As the moon revolves around the earth, the gravitational attraction flexes and deforms rocks of the earth, causing them to heat up and dissipate energy. This loss of energy means the earth rotates slower, and so the moon moves to a higher, slower orbit in order to conserve angular momentum, meaning it moves away over time.

@iamgig9876 The earth does not gain kinetic energy from the sun. The magnitude of the earths velocity is constant, because the acceleration vector towards the sun is directly perpendicular to the path of movement of the earth. Because the earth's velocity is constant, it's kinetic energy is constant.
@iamgig9876 Gravity has no effect on the velocity of the earth's rotation, gravity is a conservative field.

@iamgig9876 No, F=ma is NOT enough for the experiment, all F=ma does is give you a relation between a KNOWN force, mass and acceleration, it can't tell you what that force is. If you want to know the acceleration of a falling object, you need to know it's mass AND the force exerted on it. The magnitude of the force is given by newtons law of gravitation. You don't need to use general relativity for balls falling on earth, newtonian gravity is a perfectly accurate approximation at these scales.

@suicide1995 No, acceleration depends on force AND mass, f = ma. A heavier object has more gravitational force, but it also REQUIRES more force to accelerate it at the same rate as a lighter object. The extra force it gains from gravity and the extra force required to accelerate it balance eachother out perfectly, so that all objects will accelerate at the same rate, regardless of their mass.

@Razzfazz87 It's the exact same thing as an object falling on the earth, except now the earth is the "ball" and the sun is the "earth". @ragonfeld23  Assuming m1 is the mass of the Earth and m2 is the mass of (either) ball...

Force relates to acceleration as F = m2 * a 
The gravitational force acting between two objects is given by F = G * m1 * m2 / r^2

Equating these two cancels out m2, leaving you with a = G * m1 / r^2

So the mass of the balls is (ideally) unimportant to their acceleration under gravity.

@Zarif3000 I see it's been 3 months since you posted so I don't know if you got your answer, but inertia is a property of matter explained by one of Newton's laws. A stationary object tends to want to stay stationary, and a moving object tends to want to move at the same speed in the same direction, and will (to a degree) try to oppose forces acting on it.

@Zarif3000 Inertia is a property of matter.

@mckseal Not "generally". We physicists calculate it seldom because it is indeed complicated and we prefer to work under ideal circumstances (e.g. vacuum), but in engineering you often can't avoid doing it at least to some second-order-approximation. The effect is small in the case of a basketball and a medicine ball falling 6', but it's not small at all in as simple cases as a walnut and a leaf falling from a tree.

@ultimatt Thanks for your comment. The goal is not to make fun of others' ignorance, but to show that these ideas are common and use them as a starting point to discuss conceptions (like Newtonian physics) that have been found to be useful in understanding the world. That the 4-velocity of massive particles is c is irrelevant to the discussion and misleading for non-physicists because it sounds like massive particles can move at the speed of light which of course they can't.

@IcarusEight Yes but you may be missing the point because aerodynamics has to do with the friction of moving through air. In air feather will fall slower than a small pellet of lead that weighs the same.  But in a vacuum both would fall at the same rate.  In the demonstration both the medicine ball and the basketball have very similar shapes and are only falling a few feet. Drop them from a skyscraper on a windless day and one may hit noticeably sooner because a slight aerodynamic advantage.

The biggest problem is using language that people aren't used to.
There is no point in finding that people "talk wrongly".  Without explaining how to say it correctly.

The trick is that if the acceleration is the same, speed is the same (ignoring air resistance), but not the force. People don't fundamentally "get" physics, because all they see is "problems" and "results" rather than having a continuous mental movie about "what happens".

According to general relativity, there is no such thing as "gravitational force".  Objects in freefall have zero proper acceleration (check Wikipedia for "gravitational acceleration" if you don't believe).  Also, the magnitude of the 4-dimensional velocity of ALL particles is c, the speed of light.  No other speed is possible.  You kids think you understand physics but you don't even know about relativity, a 95-year-old theory.  Don't be so eager to make fun of others' ignorance.
